page.title: 04Farming In Oxfordshire.
page.content: We went to visit a{large farm}in our D-block, altogether it was 2000 acres and was made up of 10 individual farms. The farmer rotates three crops on most of his land. They are wheat, barley and grass. Rape has a bright yellow flower. It is grown to clean the soil and put nitrogen back into it. Mixed farming is when the land is used for different purposes. Mr. Caudwell grows crops of wheat, barley, and potatoes and is thinking of experimenting with bulbs and vines. He also keeps livestock - sheep, chickens, turkeys and cattle. Mr. Caudwell employs 13 men and 8 women. He has got 25 vehicles taxed to drive. He also has 3 combine harvesters, the most modern cost Â£62,000. Most of the land on the farm is heavy Oxfordshire clay with the exception of Warren farm where the soil is very sandy.
